artist: Artist: Kikugawa Eizan; Publisher: Izumiya Ichibei
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text: A courtesan is juxtaposed to Kisen, a mid-ninth century Buddhist monk and poet of whom we only know that he lived near Mount Uji. The inscribed poem by him is cited in the Collection of Japanese Poems of Ancient and Modern Times (Kokin wakashū) from around 905: My hut is to the capital's southeast and thus I live. But people call it "Uji, hill of one weary of the world," I hear.
title: Monk Kisen
